.comment .replyLink { color:[[ColorPalette::SecondaryDark]]; font-style: italic; 
                     cursor: pointer; text-decoration: underline; margin: 0 1em; }
.comment .created { }
.comment .newReply { color:[[ColorPalette::SecondaryDark]]; margin-top: 1em; }
.newReplyLabel { float: left; }
.closeNewReply { cursor: pointer; float: right; text-decoration: underline; }
.comments textarea { width: 100%; padding: 0.3em; margin-bottom: 0.6em; }
.newCommentArea { margin-top: 0.5em; }

.clearance { clear: both; }


!(end of StyleSheet)

***/

  config.macros.comments.init();

} // end of 'install only once'
/*}}}*/

// function log() { if (console && console.firebug) console.log.apply(console, arguments); }

no content

<html><p>The <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">USSR</a>'s launch of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sputnik" title="Sputnik" class="mw-redirect">Sputnik</a> spurred the United States to create the Advanced Research Projects Agency, known as ARPA, in February <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1958_in_science" title="1958 in science">1958</a> to regain a technological lead.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet#cite_note-1" title=""><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet#cite_note-2" title=""><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> ARPA created the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_Processing_Technology_Office" title="Information Processing Technology Office" class="mw-redirect">Information Processing Technology Office</a> (IPTO) to further the research of the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semi_Automatic_Ground_Environment" title="Semi Automatic Ground Environment">Semi Automatic Ground Environment</a> (SAGE) program, which had networked country-wide <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radar" title="Radar">radar</a> systems together for the first time. <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._C._R._Licklider" title="J. C. R. Licklider">J. C. R. Licklider</a> was selected to head the IPTO, and networking as a potential unifying human revolution.</p> <p>Licklider moved from the Psycho-Acoustic Laboratory at <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">Harvard University</a> to <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Massachusetts_Institute_of_Technology" title="Massachusetts Institute of Technology">MIT</a> in <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1950_in_science" title="1950 in science">1950</a>, after becoming interested in <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">information technology</a>. At MIT, he served on a committee that established <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_Laboratory" title="Lincoln Laboratory">Lincoln Laboratory</a> and worked on the SAGE project. In <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1957_in_science" title="1957 in science">1957</a> he became a Vice President at <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBN_Technologies" title="BBN Technologies">BBN</a>, where he bought the first production <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PDP-1" title="PDP-1">PDP-1</a> computer and conducted the first public demonstration of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-sharing" title="Time-sharing">time-sharing</a>.</p> <p>At the IPTO, Licklider got <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lawrence_Roberts_%28scientist%29" title="Lawrence Roberts (scientist)">Lawrence Roberts</a> to start a project to make a network, and Roberts based the technology on the work of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Baran" title="Paul Baran">Paul Baran</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet#cite_note-3" title=""><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> who had written an exhaustive study for the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Air_Force" title="United States Air Force">U.S. Air Force</a> that recommended <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packet_switching" title="Packet switching">packet switching</a> (as opposed to <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circuit_switching" title="Circuit switching">circuit switching</a>) to make a network highly robust and survivable. After much work, the first two nodes of what would become the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ARPANET" title="ARPANET">ARPANET</a> were interconnected between <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_California,_Los_Angeles" title="University of California, Los Angeles">UCLA</a> and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SRI_International" title="SRI International">SRI</a> (later SRI International) in <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menlo_Park" title="Menlo Park">Menlo Park</a>, California, on October 29, 1969. The ARPANET was one of the &quot;eve&quot; networks of today's Internet.</p> <p>Following on from the demonstration that packet switching worked on the ARPANET, the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Post_Office_%28United_Kingdom%29" title="General Post Office (United Kingdom)" class="mw-redirect">British Post Office</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telenet" title="Telenet">Telenet</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DATAPAC" title="DATAPAC">DATAPAC</a> and TRANSPAC collaborated to create the first international packet-switched network service. In the UK, this was referred to as the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Packet_Switched_Service" title="International Packet Switched Service">International Packet Switched Service</a> (IPSS), in <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1978_in_science" title="1978 in science">1978</a>. The collection of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X.25" title="X.25">X.25</a>-based networks grew from Europe and the US to cover Canada, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> and Australia by 1981. The X.25 packet switching standard was developed in the CCITT (now called <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITU-T" title="ITU-T">ITU-T</a>) around 1976.</p> <p>X.25 was independent of the TCP/IP protocols that arose from the experimental work of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DARPA" title="DARPA">DARPA</a> on the ARPANET, Packet Radio Net and Packet Satellite Net during the same time period. <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vinton_Cerf" title="Vinton Cerf" class="mw-redirect">Vinton Cerf</a> and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Kahn" title="Robert Kahn">Robert Kahn</a> developed the first description of the TCP protocols during 1973 and published a paper on the subject in May 1974. Use of the term &quot;Internet&quot; to describe a single global TCP/IP network originated in December 1974 with the publication of <a href="http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc675" class="external" title="http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc675">RFC 675</a>, the first full specification of TCP that was written by Vinton Cerf, Yogen Dalal and Carl Sunshine, then at Stanford University. During the next nine years, work proceeded to refine the protocols and to implement them on a wide range of operating systems.</p> <p>The first <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Protocol_Suite" title="Internet Protocol Suite">TCP/IP</a>-based wide-area network was operational by January 1, 1983 when all hosts on the ARPANET were switched over from the older NCP protocols. In 1985, the United States' <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Science_Foundation" title="National Science Foundation">National Science Foundation</a> (NSF) commissioned the construction of the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NSFNET" title="NSFNET" class="mw-redirect">NSFNET</a>, a <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University" title="University">university</a> 56 <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilobit" title="Kilobit">kilobit</a>/second network backbone using computers called &quot;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzball_router" title="Fuzzball router">fuzzballs</a>&quot; by their inventor, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_L._Mills" title="David L. Mills">David L. Mills</a>. The following year, NSF sponsored the conversion to a higher-speed 1.5&nbsp;<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mbps" title="Mbps" class="mw-redirect">megabit/second</a> network. A key decision to use the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DARPA" title="DARPA">DARPA</a> <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TCP/IP" title="TCP/IP" class="mw-redirect">TCP/IP</a> protocols was made by Dennis Jennings, then in charge of the Supercomputer program at NSF.</p> <p>The opening of the network to commercial interests began in 1988. The US Federal Networking Council approved the interconnection of the NSFNET to the commercial <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MCI_Mail" title="MCI Mail">MCI Mail</a> system in that year and the link was made in the summer of 1989. Other commercial electronic e-mail services were soon connected, including OnTyme, Telemail and Compuserve. In that same year, three commercial Internet service providers (ISP) were created: <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UUNET" title="UUNET">UUNET</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PSINet" title="PSINet">PSINet</a> and CERFNET. Important, separate networks that offered gateways into, then later merged with, the Internet include <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usenet" title="Usenet">Usenet</a> and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BITNET" title="BITNET">BITNET</a>. Various other commercial and educational networks, such as <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telenet" title="Telenet">Telenet</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tymnet" title="Tymnet">Tymnet</a>, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compuserve" title="Compuserve" class="mw-redirect">Compuserve</a> and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JANET" title="JANET">JANET</a> were interconnected with the growing Internet. <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telenet" title="Telenet">Telenet</a> (later called Sprintnet) was a large privately funded national computer network with free <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dial-up_access" title="Dial-up access" class="mw-redirect">dial-up access</a> in cities throughout the U.S. that had been in operation since the 1970s. This network was eventually interconnected with the others in the 1980s as the TCP/IP protocol became increasingly popular. The ability of TCP/IP to work over virtually any pre-existing communication networks allowed for a great ease of growth, although the rapid growth of the Internet was due primarily to the availability of commercial routers from companies such as <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cisco_Systems" title="Cisco Systems">Cisco Systems</a>, Proteon and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juniper_Networks" title="Juniper Networks">Juniper</a>, the availability of commercial <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethernet" title="Ethernet">Ethernet</a> equipment for local-area networking, and the widespread implementation of TCP/IP on the <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNIX" title="UNIX" class="mw-redirect">UNIX</a> operating system.</p></html>
[[Getting Started with MyDocs]]

<html><p>The concept of sending electronic text messages between parties in a way analogous to mailing letters or memos predates the creation of the Internet. Even today it can be important to distinguish between Internet and internal e-mail systems. Internet e-mail may travel and be stored unencrypted on many other networks and machines out of both the sender's and the recipient's control. During this time it is quite possible for the content to be read and even tampered with by third parties, if anyone considers it important enough. Purely internal or intranet mail systems, where the information never leaves the corporate or organization's network, are much more secure, although in any organization there will be <a title="Information technology" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_technology">IT</a> and other personnel whose job may involve monitoring, and occasionally accessing, the e-mail of other employees not addressed to them. Today you can send pictures and attach files on e-mail. Most e-mail servers today also feature the ability to send e-mail to multiple <a class="mw-redirect" title="E-mail addresses" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-mail_addresses">e-mail addresses</a>.</p></html>
/***
|''Name:''|FadingMessagesPlugin|
|''Description:''|Automatically clear a displayed message after an interval |
|''Author:''|PaulDowney (psd (at) osmosoft (dot) com) |
|''Source:''|http://whatfettle.com/2008/07/FadingMessagesPlugin/ |
|''CodeRepository:''|http://svn.tiddlywiki.org/Trunk/contributors/PaulDowney/plugins/FadingMessagesPlugin/ |
|''Version:''|0.2|
|''License:''|[[BSD License|http://www.opensource.org/licenses/bsd-license.php]] |
|''Comments:''|Please make comments at http://groups.google.co.uk/group/TiddlyWikiDev |
|''~CoreVersion:''|2.4|
|''Overrides:''|displayMessage|
|''Requires:''|WikifiedMessagesPlugin|
!!Documentation
Displayed messages automatically fade away after a short interval. 
!!Options
|<<option txtFadingMessagesTimeout>>|<<message config.optionsDesc.txtFadingMessagesTimeout>>|
|<<option chkAnimate>>|<<message config.optionsDesc.chkAnimate>>|
!!Code
***/
//{{{
if(!version.extensions.FadingMessagesPlugin) {
version.extensions.FadingMessagesPlugin = {installed:true};

	config.options.txtFadingMessagesTimeout = 5;
	config.optionsDesc.txtFadingMessagesTimeout = "seconds before a displayed message clears itself";

	config.animDurationFade = 900;

	config.extensions.FadingMessages = {
		Fader: function(e,done)
		{
			e.style.overflow = 'hidden';
			e.style.display = 'block';
			var p = [];
			p.push({style: 'display', atEnd: 'none'});
			p.push({style: 'opacity', start: 1, end: 0, template: '%0'});
			p.push({style: 'filter', start: 100, end: 0, template: 'alpha(opacity:%0)'});
			return new Morpher(e,config.animDurationFade,p,done);
		},  
		clearMessageBox: function(e)
		{
			try { removeNode(e); } catch(ex) {}
			var msgArea = document.getElementById("messageArea");
			var n = msgArea.getElementsByTagName('div');
			if(!(n&&n.length)){
				msgArea.style.display = "none";
			}
		},
		fadeMessageBox: function(e)
		{
			var me = config.extensions.FadingMessages;
			if(config.options.chkAnimate && anim){
				anim.startAnimating(new me.Fader(e,me.clearMessageBox));
			}else{
				me.clearMessageBox(e);
			}
		},
		createClearAllButton: function(e)
		{
			return null;
		},
		createClearMessageButton: function(e)
		{
			var me = config.extensions.FadingMessages;
			return createTiddlyButton(createTiddlyElement(e,"span",null,"messageClear"),
				"×","",
				function(){me.clearMessageBox(e);});
		},
		_displayMessage: displayMessage,
		displayMessage: function(text,linkText)
		{
			var me = config.extensions.FadingMessages;
			var e = me._displayMessage(text,linkText);
			if(e){
				window.setTimeout(function(){me.fadeMessageBox(e);},config.options.txtFadingMessagesTimeout*1000);
			}
			return e;
		}
	};

	displayMessage = config.extensions.FadingMessages.displayMessage;
	config.extensions.WikifiedMessages.createClearMessageButton = config.extensions.FadingMessages.createClearMessageButton;
	config.extensions.WikifiedMessages.createClearAllButton = config.extensions.FadingMessages.createClearAllButton;
}
//}}}

<html><p>A <a title="Computer file" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_file">computer file</a> can be <a class="mw-redirect" title="Electronic mail" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_mail">e-mailed</a> to customers, colleagues and friends as an <a title="E-mail attachment" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-mail_attachment">attachment</a>. It can be uploaded to a <a title="Website" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Website">website</a> or <a title="File Transfer Protocol" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File_Transfer_Protocol">FTP</a> server for easy download by others. It can be put into a &quot;shared location&quot; or onto a <a title="File server" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File_server">file server</a> for instant use by colleagues. The load of bulk downloads to many users can be eased by the use of &quot;<a title="Mirror (computing)" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mirror_%28computing%29">mirror</a>&quot; servers or <a title="Peer-to-peer" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peer-to-peer">peer-to-peer</a> networks.</p> <p>In any of these cases, access to the file may be controlled by user <a title="Authentication" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authentication">authentication</a>, the transit of the file over the Internet may be obscured by <a title="Encryption" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Encryption">encryption</a>, and money may change hands for access to the file. The price can be paid by the remote charging of funds from, for example, a credit card whose details are also passed&mdash;hopefully fully encrypted&mdash;across the Internet. The origin and authenticity of the file received may be checked by <a title="Digital signature" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_signature">digital signatures</a> or by <a title="MD5" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MD5">MD5</a> or other message digests.</p> <p>These simple features of the Internet, over a worldwide basis, are changing the production, sale, and distribution of anything that can be reduced to a computer file for transmission. This includes all manner of print publications, software products, news, music, film, video, photography, graphics and the other arts. This in turn has caused seismic shifts in each of the existing industries that previously controlled the production and distribution of these products.</p></html>
<html><p>Although the basic applications and guidelines that make the Internet possible had existed for almost two decades, the network did not gain a public face until the 1990s. On 6 August 1991, <a title="CERN" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CERN">CERN</a>, a pan European organisation for particle research, publicized the new <a title="World Wide Web" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web">World Wide Web</a> project. The Web was invented by <a title="England" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/England">English</a> scientist <a title="Tim Berners-Lee" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee">Tim Berners-Lee</a> in 1989.</p> <p>An early popular <a title="Web browser" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_browser">web browser</a> was <a title="ViolaWWW" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ViolaWWW">ViolaWWW</a>, patterned after <a title="HyperCard" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HyperCard">HyperCard</a> and built using the <a title="X Window System" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X_Window_System">X Window System</a>. It was eventually replaced in popularity by the <a title="Mosaic (web browser)" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosaic_%28web_browser%29">Mosaic</a> web browser. In 1993, the <a title="National Center for Supercomputing Applications" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Center_for_Supercomputing_Applications">National Center for Supercomputing Applications</a> at the <a title="University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Illinois_at_Urbana-Champaign">University of Illinois</a> released version 1.0 of Mosaic, and by late 1994 there was growing public interest in the previously academic, technical Internet. By 1996 usage of the word <i>Internet</i> had become commonplace, and consequently, so had its use as a <a title="Synecdoche" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synecdoche">synecdoche</a> in reference to the World Wide Web.</p> <p>Meanwhile, over the course of the decade, the Internet successfully accommodated the majority of previously existing public computer networks (although some networks, such as <a title="FidoNet" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FidoNet">FidoNet</a>, have remained separate). During the 1990s, it was estimated that the Internet grew by 100% per year, with a brief period of explosive growth in 1996 and 1997.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a title="" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> This growth is often attributed to the lack of central administration, which allows organic growth of the network, as well as the non-proprietary open nature of the Internet protocols, which encourages vendor interoperability and prevents any one company from exerting too much control over the network. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a title="" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Using various statistics, <a title="Advanced Micro Devices" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Micro_Devices">AMD</a> estimated the population of internet users to be 1.5 billion as of January 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a title="" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p><p><img src="http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Internet_users_per_100_inhabitants_1997-2007_ITU.png/300px-Internet_users_per_100_inhabitants_1997-2007_ITU.png" alt="" /></p><p><img alt="" src="file:///Users/simonmcmanus/Library/Caches/TemporaryItems/moz-screenshot.jpg" /></p></html>
(function() {

var _saveOptionCookie = saveOptionCookie;
saveOptionCookie = function(name) {
	arguments[0] = name.replace(/[()\s]/g, "_");
	return _saveOptionCookie.apply(this, arguments);
};

})();
...

<html><p>The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is the authority that coordinates the assignment of unique identifiers on the Internet, including <a title="Domain name" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain_name">domain names</a>, Internet Protocol (IP) addresses, and protocol port and parameter numbers. A globally unified namespace (i.e., a system of names in which there is at most one holder for each possible name) is essential for the Internet to function. ICANN is headquartered in <a title="Marina del Rey, California" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marina_del_Rey,_California">Marina del Rey, California</a>, but is overseen by an international board of directors drawn from across the Internet technical, business, academic, and non-commercial communities. The US government continues to have the primary role in approving changes to the <a title="DNS root zone" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNS_root_zone">root zone</a> file that lies at the heart of the domain name system. Because the Internet is a distributed network comprising many voluntarily interconnected networks, the Internet has no governing body. ICANN's role in coordinating the assignment of unique identifiers distinguishes it as perhaps the only central coordinating body on the global Internet, but the scope of its authority extends only to the Internet's systems of domain names, <a title="IP address" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IP_address">IP addresses</a>, protocol ports and parameter numbers.</p> <p>On November 16, 2005, the <a title="World Summit on the Information Society" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Summit_on_the_Information_Society">World Summit on the Information Society</a>, held in <a title="Tunis" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tunis">Tunis</a>, established the <a title="Internet Governance Forum" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Governance_Forum">Internet Governance Forum</a> (IGF) to discuss Internet-related issues.</p></html>
<html><p>VoIP stands for Voice-over-<a title="Internet Protocol" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Protocol">Internet Protocol</a>, referring to the protocol that underlies all Internet communication. The idea began in the early 1990s with <a title="Walkie-talkie" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walkie-talkie">walkie-talkie</a>-like voice applications for personal computers. In recent years many VoIP systems have become as easy to use and as convenient as a normal telephone. The benefit is that, as the Internet carries the voice traffic, VoIP can be free or cost much less than a traditional telephone call, especially over long distances and especially for those with always-on Internet connections such as <a title="Cable modem" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cable_modem">cable</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" title="ADSL" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ADSL">ADSL</a>.</p> <p>VoIP is maturing into a competitive alternative to traditional telephone service. Interoperability between different providers has improved and the ability to call or receive a call from a traditional telephone is available. Simple, inexpensive VoIP network adapters are available that eliminate the need for a personal computer.</p> <p>Voice quality can still vary from call to call but is often equal to and can even exceed that of traditional calls.</p> <p>Remaining problems for VoIP include <a title="Emergency telephone number" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergency_telephone_number">emergency telephone number</a> dialling and reliability. Currently, a few VoIP providers provide an emergency service, but it is not universally available. Traditional phones are line-powered and operate during a power failure; VoIP does not do so without a <a title="Uninterruptible power supply" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uninterruptible_power_supply">backup power source</a> for the phone equipment and the Internet access devices.</p> <p>VoIP has also become increasingly popular for gaming applications, as a form of communication between players. Popular VoIP clients for gaming include <a title="Ventrilo" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ventrilo">Ventrilo</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" title="Teamspeak" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teamspeak">Teamspeak</a>, and others. <a title="PlayStation 3" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PlayStation_3">PlayStation 3</a> and <a title="Xbox 360" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_360">Xbox 360</a> also offer VoIP chat features.</p></html>
<html><p>Common methods of home access include <a class="mw-redirect" title="Dial-up internet access" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dial-up_internet_access">dial-up</a>, landline <a title="Broadband Internet access" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadband_Internet_access">broadband</a> (over coaxial cable, <a class="mw-redirect" title="Fiber optic" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiber_optic">fiber optic</a> or copper wires), <a title="Wi-Fi" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wi-Fi">Wi-Fi</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" title="Satellite Internet" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satellite_Internet">satellite</a> and <a title="3G" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3G">3G</a> technology <a title="Mobile phone" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_phone">cell phones</a>.</p> <p>Public places to use the Internet include libraries and <a class="mw-redirect" title="Internet cafe" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_cafe">Internet cafes</a>, where computers with Internet connections are available. There are also <a class="mw-redirect" title="Internet kiosk" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_kiosk">Internet access points</a> in many public places such as airport halls and coffee shops, in some cases just for brief use while standing. Various terms are used, such as &quot;public Internet kiosk&quot;, &quot;public access terminal&quot;, and &quot;Web <a title="Payphone" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Payphone">payphone</a>&quot;. Many hotels now also have public terminals, though these are usually fee-based. These terminals are widely accessed for various usage like ticket booking, bank deposit, online payment etc. Wi-Fi provides wireless access to computer networks, and therefore can do so to the Internet itself. <a title="Hotspot (Wi-Fi)" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotspot_%28Wi-Fi%29">Hotspots</a> providing such access include <a title="Wi-Fi" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wi-Fi#Commercial_Wi-Fi">Wi-Fi cafes</a>, where would-be users need to bring their own wireless-enabled devices such as a <a title="Laptop" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laptop">laptop</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" title="Personal Digital Assistant" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_Digital_Assistant">PDA</a>. These services may be free to all, free to customers only, or fee-based. A hotspot need not be limited to a confined location. A whole campus or park, or even an entire city can be enabled. <a title="Grassroots" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grassroots">Grassroots</a> efforts have led to <a title="Wireless community network" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_community_network">wireless community networks</a>. Commercial Wi-Fi services covering large city areas are in place in <a title="London" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/London">London</a>, <a title="Vienna" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vienna">Vienna</a>, <a title="Toronto" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toronto">Toronto</a>, <a title="San Francisco" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco">San Francisco</a>, <a title="Philadelphia" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, <a title="Chicago" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago">Chicago</a> and <a title="Pittsburgh" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a>. The Internet can then be accessed from such places as a park bench.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a title="" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet#cite_note-13"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Apart from Wi-Fi, there have been experiments with proprietary mobile wireless networks like <a title="Ricochet (internet service)" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ricochet_%28internet_service%29">Ricochet</a>, various high-speed data services over cellular phone networks, and fixed wireless services.</p> <p>High-end mobile phones such as <a title="Smartphone" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smartphone">smartphones</a> generally come with Internet access through the phone network. Web browsers such as <a title="Opera (web browser)" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opera_%28web_browser%29">Opera</a> are available on these advanced handsets, which can also run a wide variety of other Internet software. More mobile phones have Internet access than PCs, though this is not as widely used. An Internet access provider and protocol matrix differentiates the methods used to get online.</p> <table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="5" border="1" style="font-size: 70%; width: 100%;" class="wikitable collapsible" id="collapsibleTable0"><tbody><tr> <th colspan="9"><span class="collapseButton">[<a id="collapseButton0" href="javascript:collapseTable(0);">hide</a>]</span>Internet Access</th> </tr> <tr> <th rowspan="2">Network Type</th> <th colspan="5">Wired</th> <th colspan="3">Wireless</th> </tr> <tr> <th>Optical</th> <th>Coaxial Cable</th> <th>Ethernet Cable</th> <th>Phone line</th> <th>Power line</th> <th>Unlicensed terrestrial bands</th> <th>Licensed terrestrial bands</th> <th>Satellite</th> </tr> <tr> <th><a class="mw-redirect" title="Local Area Network" network" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Passive_optical_network">PON</a></td> <td><a title="DOCSIS" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOCSIS">DOCSIS</a></td> <td>&nbsp;</td> <td><a class="mw-redirect" title="Dial-up" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dial-up">Dial-up</a><span style="font-weight: bold;">&nbsp;&middot;</span> <a class="mw-redirect" title="ISDN" The Internet is allowing greater flexibility in working hours and location, especially with the spread of unmetered high-speed connections and Web applications.
...

<html><p>The complex communications infrastructure of the Internet consists of its hardware components and a system of software layers that control various aspects of the architecture. While the hardware can often be used to support other software systems, it is the design and the rigorous standardization process of the software architecture that characterizes the Internet.</p> <p>The responsibility for the architectural design of the Internet software systems has been delegated to the <a title="Internet Engineering Task Force" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Engineering_Task_Force">Internet Engineering Task Force</a> (IETF).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a title="" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet#cite_note-9"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup> The IETF conducts standard-setting work groups, open to any individual, about the various aspects of Internet architecture. Resulting discussions and final standards are published in <a class="mw-redirect" title="Request for Comment" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Request_for_Comment">Requests for Comments</a> (RFCs), freely available on the IETF web site.</p> <p>The principal methods of networking that enable the Internet are contained in a series of RFCs that constitute the <a class="mw-redirect" title="Internet Standard" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Standard">Internet Standards</a>. These standards describe a system known as the <a class="mw-redirect" title="Internet protocol suite" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_protocol_suite">Internet Protocol Suite</a>. This is a model architecture that divides methods into a layered system of protocols (<a title="http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1122" class="external" href="http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1122">RFC 1122</a>, <a title="http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1123" class="external" href="http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1123">RFC 1123</a>). The layers correspond to the environment or scope in which their services operate. At the top is the space (<a class="mw-redirect" title="Application layer" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_layer">Application Layer</a>) of the software application, e.g., a web browser application, and just below it is the <a class="mw-redirect" title="Transport layer" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_layer">Transport Layer</a> which connects applications on different hosts via the network (e.g., <a title="Client-server" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Client-server">client-server</a> model). The underlying network consists of two layers: the <a class="mw-redirect" title="Internet layer" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_layer">Internet Layer</a> which enables computers to connect to one-another via intermediate (transit) networks and thus is the layer that establishes <a title="Internetworking" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internetworking">internetworking</a> and the Internet, and lastly, at the bottom, is a software layer that provides connectivity between hosts on the same local link (therefor called <a class="mw-redirect" title="Link layer" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Link_layer">Link Layer</a>), e.g., a local area network (<a class="mw-redirect" title="LAN" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LAN">LAN</a>) or a <a class="mw-redirect" title="Dial-up internet access" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dial-up_internet_access">dial-up connection</a>. This model is also known as the <a class="mw-redirect" title="TCP/IP" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TCP/IP">TCP/IP</a> model of networking. While other models have been developed, such as the <a title="Open Systems Interconnection" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Systems_Interconnection">Open Systems Interconnection</a> (OSI) model, they are not compatible in the details of description, nor implementation.</p> <p>The most prominent component of the Internet model is the <a title="Internet Protocol" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_Protocol">Internet Protocol</a> (IP) which provides addressing systems for computers on the Internet and facilitates the <a title="Internetworking" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internetworking">internetworking</a> of networks. IP Version 4 (<a title="IPv4" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPv4">IPv4</a>) is the initial version used on the first generation of the today's Internet and is still in dominant use. It was designed to address up to ~4.3 billion (10<sup>9</sup>) Internet hosts. However, the explosive growth of the Internet has led to <a title="IPv4 address exhaustion" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPv4_address_exhaustion">IPv4 address exhaustion</a>. A new protocol version, <a title="IPv6" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPv6">IPv6</a>, was developed which provides vastly larger addressing capabilities and more efficient routing of data traffic. <a title="IPv6" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPv6">IPv6</a> is currently in commercial <a title="IPv6 deployment" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IPv6_deployment">deployment</a> phase around the world.</p> <p>IPv6 is not interoperable with IPv4. It essentially establishes a &quot;parallel&quot; version of the Internet not accessible with IPv4 software. This means software upgrades are necessary for every networking device that needs to communicate on the IPv6 Internet. Most modern computer operating systems are already converted to operate with both versions of the Internet Protocol. Network infrastructures, however, are still lagging in this development.</p></html>
<html><h3>&nbsp;</h3> <p>There have been many analyses of the Internet and its structure. For example, it has been determined that both the Internet IP routing structure and hypertext links of the World Wide Web are examples of <a title="Scale-free network" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scale-free_network">scale-free networks</a>.</p> <p>Similar to the way the commercial Internet providers connect via <a title="Internet exchange point" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_exchange_point">Internet exchange points</a>, research networks tend to interconnect into large subnetworks such as the following:</p> <ul><li><a class="mw-redirect" title="GEANT" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GEANT">GEANT</a></li><li><a title="GLORIAD" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GLORIAD">GLORIAD</a></li><li>The <a title="Internet2" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet2">Internet2</a> Network (formally known as the <a title="Abilene Network" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abilene_Network">Abilene Network</a>)</li><li><a title="JANET" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JANET">JANET</a> (the UK's <a title="National research and education network" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_research_and_education_network">national research and education network</a>)</li></ul> <p>These in turn are built around relatively smaller networks. See also the list of <a title="Category:Academic computer network organizations" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Academic_computer_network_organizations">academic computer network organizations</a>.</p> <p><a title="Computer network diagram" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_network_diagram">Computer network diagrams</a> often represent the Internet using a cloud symbol from which network communications pass in and out.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a title="" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet#cite_note-10"><span>[</span>11<span>]</span></a></sup></p></html>
(function ($) {
    var m = {
            '\b': '\\b',
            '\t': '\\t',
            '\n': '\\n',
            '\f': '\\f',
            '\r': '\\r',
            '"' : '\\"',
            '\\': '\\\\'
        },
        s = {
            'array': function (x) {
                var a = ['['], b, f, i, l = x.length, v;
                for (i = 0; i < l; i += 1) {
                    v = x[i];
                    f = s[typeof v];
                    if (f) {
                        v = f(v);
                        if (typeof v == 'string') {
                            if (b) {
                                a[a.length] = ',';
                            }
                            a[a.length] = v;
                            b = true;
                        }
                    }
                }
                a[a.length] = ']';
                return a.join('');
            },
            'boolean': function (x) {
                return String(x);
            },
            'null': function (x) {
                return "null";
            },
            'number': function (x) {
                return isFinite(x) ? String(x) : 'null';
            },
            'object': function (x) {
                if (x) {
                    if (x instanceof Array) {
                        return s.array(x);
                    }
                    var a = ['{'], b, f, i, v;
                    for (i in x) {
                        v = x[i];
                        f = s[typeof v];
                        if (f) {
                            v = f(v);
                            if (typeof v == 'string') {
                                if (b) {
                                    a[a.length] = ',';
                                }
                                a.push(s.string(i), ':', v);
                                b = true;
                            }
                        }
                    }
                    a[a.length] = '}';
                    return a.join('');
                }
                return 'null';
            },
            'string': function (x) {
                if (/["\\\x00-\x1f]/.test(x)) {
                    x = x.replace(/([\x00-\x1f\\"])/g, function(a, b) {
                        var c = m[b];
                        if (c) {
                            return c;
                        }
                        c = b.charCodeAt();
                        return '\\u00' +
                            Math.floor(c / 16).toString(16) +
                            (c % 16).toString(16);
                    });
                }
                return '"' + x + '"';
            }
        };

	$.toJSON = function(v) {
		var f = isNaN(v) ? s[typeof v] : s['number'];
		if (f) return f(v);
	};
	
	$.parseJSON = function(v, safe) {
		if (safe === undefined) safe = $.parseJSON.safe;
		if (safe && !/^("(\\.|[^"\\\n\r])*?"|[,:{}\[\]0-9.\-+Eaeflnr-u \n\r\t])+?$/.test(v))
			return undefined;
		return eval('('+v+')');
	};
	
	$.parseJSON.safe = false;

})(jQuery);

<html><p>The prevalent language for communication on the Internet is <a title="English language" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_language">English</a>. This may be a result of the Internet's origins, as well as English's role as a <a title="Lingua franca" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lingua_franca">lingua franca</a>. It may also be related to the poor capability of early computers, largely originating in the United States, to handle characters other than those in the English variant of the <a title="Latin alphabet" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_alphabet">Latin alphabet</a>.</p> <p>After English (28.6% of Web visitors) the most requested languages on the <a title="World Wide Web" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web">World Wide Web</a> are <a title="Chinese language" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_language">Chinese</a> (20.3%), <a title="Spanish language" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_language">Spanish</a> (8.2%), <a title="Japanese language" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_language">Japanese</a> (5.9%), <a title="French language" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_language">French</a> and <a title="Portuguese language" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portuguese_language">Portuguese</a> (4.6%), <a title="German language" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_language">German</a> (4.1%), <a title="Arabic language" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabic_language">Arabic</a> (2.6%), <a title="Russian language" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_language">Russian</a> (2.4%), and <a title="Korean language" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korean_language">Korean</a> (2.3%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a title="" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet#cite_note-11"><span>[</span>12<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>By region, 41% of the world's Internet users are based in <a title="Asia" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asia">Asia</a>, 25% in <a title="Europe" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Europe">Europe</a>, 16% in <a title="North America" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_America">North America</a>, 11% in <a title="Latin America" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_America">Latin America</a> and the <a title="Caribbean" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caribbean">Caribbean</a>, 3% in <a title="Africa" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Africa">Africa</a>, 3% in the <a title="Middle East" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_East">Middle East</a> and 1% in Australia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inetstats_8-1"><a title="" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet#cite_note-inetstats-8"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>The Internet's technologies have developed enough in recent years, especially in the use of <a title="Unicode" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unicode">Unicode</a>, that good facilities are available for development and communication in most widely used languages. However, some glitches such as <i><a title="Mojibake" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mojibake">mojibake</a></i> (incorrect display of foreign language characters, also known as <i>kryakozyabry</i>) still remain.</p></html>
<html><p>The Internet has been a major source of leisure since before the World Wide Web, with entertaining social experiments such as <a title="MUD" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MUD">MUDs</a> and <a title="MOO" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MOO">MOOs</a> being conducted on university servers, and humor-related <a title="Usenet" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usenet">Usenet</a> groups receiving much of the main traffic. Today, many <a title="Internet forum" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_forum">Internet forums</a> have sections devoted to games and funny videos; short cartoons in the form of <a title="Flash animation" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flash_animation">Flash movies</a> are also popular. Over 6 million people use blogs or message boards as a means of communication and for the sharing of ideas.</p> <p>The <a title="Pornography" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pornography">pornography</a> and <a title="Gambling" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gambling">gambling</a> industries have both taken full advantage of the World Wide Web, and often provide a significant source of advertising revenue for other websites. Although many governments have attempted to put restrictions on both industries' use of the Internet, this has generally failed to stop their widespread popularity.</p> <p>One main area of leisure on the Internet is <a class="mw-redirect" title="Multiplayer gaming" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiplayer_gaming">multiplayer gaming</a>. This form of leisure creates communities, bringing people of all ages and origins to enjoy the fast-paced world of multiplayer games. These range from <a class="mw-redirect" title="MMORPG" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MMORPG">MMORPG</a> to <a title="First-person shooter" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First-person_shooter">first-person shooters</a>, from <a title="Computer role-playing game" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_role-playing_game">role-playing games</a> to <a title="Online gambling" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_gambling">online gambling</a>. This has revolutionized the way many people interact and spend their free time on the Internet.</p> <p>While online gaming has been around since the 1970s, modern modes of online gaming began with services such as <a title="GameSpy Arcade" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GameSpy_Arcade">GameSpy</a> and <a title="MPlayer.com" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MPlayer.com">MPlayer</a>, to which players of games would typically subscribe. Non-subscribers were limited to certain types of gameplay or certain games.</p> <p>Many use the Internet to access and download music, movies and other works for their enjoyment and relaxation. As discussed above, there are paid and unpaid sources for all of these, using centralized servers and distributed peer-to-peer technologies. Some of these sources take more care over the original artists' rights and over copyright laws than others.</p> <p>Many use the World Wide Web to access news, weather and sports reports, to plan and book holidays and to find out more about their random ideas and casual interests.</p> <p>People use <a title="Online chat" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_chat">chat</a>, <a title="Instant messaging" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instant_messaging">messaging</a> and e-mail to make and stay in touch with friends worldwide, sometimes in the same way as some previously had <a title="Pen pal" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pen_pal">pen pals</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" title="Social networking" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking">Social networking</a> websites like <a title="MySpace" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MySpace">MySpace</a>, <a title="Facebook" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook">Facebook</a> and many others like them also put and keep people in contact for their enjoyment.</p> <p>The Internet has seen a growing number of <a title="Web desktop" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Web_desktop">Web desktops</a>, where users can access their files, folders, and settings via the Internet.</p> <p><a class="mw-redirect" title="Cyberslacking" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyberslacking">Cyberslacking</a> has become a serious drain on corporate resources; the average UK employee spends 57 minutes a day surfing the Web at work, according to a study by Peninsula Business Services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a title="" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet#cite_note-15"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup></p></html>
<<docMenu>>
<<deleteZone>>



...

<script type="text/javascript" src="/doccollab/static/ckeditor/ckeditor.js"></script>

..

The Internet allows computer users to connect to other computers and information stores easily, wherever they may be across the world. They may do this with or without the use of security, authentication and encryption technologies, depending on the requirements.<br /><br />This is encouraging new ways of working from home, collaboration and information sharing in many industries. An accountant sitting at home can audit the books of a company based in another country, on a server situated in a third country that is remotely maintained by IT specialists in a fourth. These accounts could have been created by home-working bookkeepers, in other remote locations, based on information e-mailed to them from offices all over the world. Some of these things were possible before the widespread use of the Internet, but the cost of private leased lines would have made many of them infeasible in practice.<br /><br />An office worker away from his desk, perhaps on the other side of the world on a business trip or a holiday, can open a remote desktop session into his normal office PC using a secure Virtual Private Network (VPN) connection via the Internet. This gives the worker complete access to all of his or her normal files and data, including e-mail and other applications, while away from the office.<br /><br />This concept is also referred to by some network security people as the Virtual Private Nightmare, because it extends the secure perimeter of a corporate network into its employees' homes.</p></html>
!Configuration Options
